awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Air-Breathing Electric Propulsion
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to create reusable satellites that can refuel directly from the Earth’s atmosphere. These satellites will have two key advantages over the existing satellites. First, they will fly significantly lower than current satellites providing superior Earth Observation and satellite broadband communication quality. Second, they will enable refuellable space tugs that can perform a servicing mission and then descend into the atmosphere to refuel. Furthermore, by flying in these low orbits, satellites will naturally de-orbit at the end of life and leave orbits uncluttered. Finally, the proposed space tugs will reduce the need for powerful chemical rockets (for both launch and in-space maneuvers). 

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to investigate satellite air-breathing electric propulsion. While technologies necessary to enable air-breathing electric propulsion have been maturing for the last few decades, a viable system has not yet been demonstrated. This project will address the last remaining technological gap to enable a viable air-breathing electric propulsion system that will unlock access to ultra-low Earth orbits (ULEO), between 200 km and 300 km. The propulsion system consists of an electric propulsion thruster, such as a Hall Effect Thruster (HET) and an air-scoop that collects atmospheric air. This proposed project presents the first step in developing such a system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As humanity is experiencing the dawn of a new space age, many of our technologies are ripe for an update. One of the largest unsolved problems in space is the limited onboard propellant that determines the useful life of a satellite. We still launch disposable multi-million-dollar satellites that have a life determined by the amount of propellant originally brought on-board and launched from Earth. Viridian Space Corporation is addressing this fundamental challenge. We are developing the world’s first satellite air-breathing electric propulsion system, which will enable satellites to refuel from the atmosphere while in flight. This technology will allow satellites to fly lower and longer than ever before, easing congestion, improving sensing and communication capabilities, and lowering the cost of operation.

In order to use the rarified atmosphere to refuel, Viridian’s propulsion system requires both an efficient air-harvesting system and a plasma thruster that can use the harvested air. In this project, the first prototypes of our air-harvester were tested and demonstrated that they could efficiently collect high-speed gases that a satellite will fly through in very low orbits. Viridian built a vacuum test facility that could be used to create high-speed gas flow and also implemented diagnostics to accurately measure the performance of our air-harvesters in this environment. Simultaneously, the performance of our harvesters was numerically modeled -- there was strong agreement between our experimental and numerical results. This ensures that the numerical modeling tools can be used for future design work to further improve air-breathing electric propulsion capabilities.

Finally, because of the unique environment that satellites flying in very low Earth orbits must experience, we investigated the trade-offs between flight at traditional low-Earth orbits and the very low orbits that Viridian-enabled satellites can reach. Viridian anticipates presenting results of this effort at the 2024 International Electric Propulsion Conference.
